page.title: 01Swanbourne and Hoggeston
page.content: Swanbourne is situated at the westward end of a sand and gravel outcrop overlooking the lowlying heavy wetlands astride the Claydon Brook which is a major source of the Great Ouse. The village is of Anglo-Saxon origin,having the outlines and street pattern of a major settlement of that period,recognisable in the surviving home closes of yeomen farmers who numbered 48 at the time of enclosure in 1763. The name of the village may be derived from Suen,Earl of Essex,about 1050,or from "the stream frequented by swans". Two km south,across arable fields and pasture lands,lies the small village of Hoggeston with the remains of its stockaded ring bank.
